In this lesson, we will learn how to use a tree diagram in determining all possible outcomes of a compound event and finding the number of ways a compound event may occur using the fundamental principle of counting.

There are 6 possible choices of outfit that Camila could choose to wear.\n\nHere is another example of using the tree diagram to count the number of possible outcomes. Suppose that a married couple wishes to have three children in their family,

(a) how many possible outcomes for the genders of the family?

(b) how many of all three children will have the same gender?
(c) how many have exactly two of the three children will be girls?
(d) how many have at least one of the three children will be girls?
(e) how many have none of the three children will be a boy?
(a) The list of possible outcomes for the genders of the family are BBB, BBG, BGB, BGG, GBB, GBG, GGB, and GGG. There are 8 possible outcomes.

(b) The three children of the same gender are BBB and GGG. There are 2 possible outcomes.

(c) The children which have exactly two of them are girls are BGG, GBG, and GGB. There are 3 possible outcomes.

(d) The word “at least one of them is a girl” means having one or more girls in the family. The children which have at least one of them will be a girl are BBG, BGB, BGG, GBB, GBG, GGB, and GGG. There are 7 possible outcomes.

(e) None of them will be a boy can also be stated as all of the three children are girls. Thus, the only possible outcome is GGG. There is only 1 possible outcome.

The tree diagram was helpful in illustrating the list of possible combinations of outcomes in the two examples presented above. Similarly, we can also count the total number of outcomes without the need to list the possible combinations of outcomes through the use of the Fundamental Counting Principle (FCP).

(a) How many 3-digit numbers digits can be formed if repetition is allowed?\n(b) How many of these 3-digit numbers are even if repetition is allowed?\n(c) How many of these 3-digit numbers are odd if repetition is not allowed?
Show Solution

(a) Since zero cannot be used as the first digit, therefore, there are nine choices left for the first digit. The second digit and the third digit can be chosen in 10 ways since repetition is allowed.

(b) Since zero cannot be used as the first digit, therefore, there are nine choices left for the first digit. To be an even number, the last number can be 0, 2, 4, 6, or 8 which gives us 5 choices. The second digit can be chosen in 10 ways since repetition is allowed.

(c) Since zero cannot be used as the first digit, therefore, there are nine choices left for the first digit. To be an odd number, the last number can be 1, 3, 5, 7, 9 which gives us 5 choices. Since the two digits were already used up to occupy the 1st and the 3rd digit and repetition is not allowed, therefore the second digit can be chosen in 8 ways.
